{{Infobox airport | name = RAF Long Marston | nativename = [[Image:Ensign of the Royal Air Force.svg|90px]] | nativename-a = | nativename-r = | image = | image-width = | caption = | IATA = | ICAO = | type = Military | owner = [[Air Ministry]] | operator = [[Royal Air Force]] | city-served = | location = [[Long Marston, Warwickshire|Long Marston]], [[Warwickshire]] | built = {{Start date|1940}} | used = 1941-{{End date|1958}} | elevation-f = {{Convert|47|m|disp=output number only|0}} | elevation-m = 47 | coordinates = {{Coord|52|08|15|N|001|45|09|W|region:GB_type:airport|display=inline,title}} | latd = 52 | latm = 08 | lats = 15 | latNS = N | longd= 001 | longm= 45 | longs= 09 | longEW= W | coordinates_type = airport | coordinates_region = GB | pushpin_map = Warwickshire | pushpin_label = RAF Long Marston | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Warwickshire | website = | r1-number = 04/22 | r1-length-f = 0 | r1-length-m = 0 | r1-surface = Asphalt | r2-number = 11/29 | r2-length-f = 0 | r2-length-m = 0 | r2-surface = Asphalt | r3-number = 16/34 | r3-length-f = 0 | r3-length-m = 0 | r3-surface = Asphalt | stat-year = | stat1-header = | stat1-data = | stat2-header = | stat2-data = | footnotes = }} '''RAF Long Marston''' was opened in 1941 and was in the county of Warwickshire,<ref name="AW">{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantikwall.co.uk/atlantikwall/warwickshire/long_marston01/html/page02.htm |title=RAF Long Marston |publisher=Atlantik Wall|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> England
==History==
It had two T2 [[hangar]]s and one B1 hangar. The airfield had a mixture of 27 pan dispersals and spectacle dispersals which were used to disperse the aircraft around the airfield in case of enemy attack or accidents which could wreck multiple aircraft if bunched together this was connected to the [[Class A airfield|regular 3-runway layout]]. The airfield was constructed by John Laing & Son<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.longmarstonairfield.com/History.aspx |title=Our History - Warwickshire's angry skies |publisher=Long Marston Airfield|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> which also created a number of other local airfields including [[Wellesbourne Mountford Airfield|RAF Wellesbourne Mountford]]. The airfield closed on 28 January 1958.<ref name="ABCT">{{cite web|url=http://www.abct.org.uk/airfields/long-marston |title=RAF Long Marston |publisher=Airfields of Britain Conservation Trust|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
==Based units==
The first unit to inhabite the airfield was [[No. 24 OTU|No. 24 Operational Training Unit]] (OTU) which used [[Armstrong Whitworth Whitley]]s, [[Avro Anson]]s and [[Vickers Wellington]]s beginning 15 March 1943 as a satellite of [[RAF Honeybourne]] before the unit closed on 24 July 1945. The Whitleys joined the unit after retiring from frontline service as an early [[Second World War]] night bomber when new four engined bombers like the [[Avro Lancaster]] took over the [[Strategic bombing during World War II|offensive]].<ref name="AAFLU">{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationarchaeology.org.uk/marg/flying_units.htm |title=Flying units in the south west midlands |publisher=Aviation Archaeology|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
Another unit to use the airfield was [[No. 1681 Flight RAF]] with [[Hawker Hurricane]]s and [[Curtiss P-40 variants#Hawk 81A-1.2FP-40B.2FP-40C .28British Commonwealth.2FSoviet .22Tomahawk Mk I.22 and .22Tomahawk Mk IIA and IIB.22.29|Tomahawk]]s providing simulated attacks against OTU aircraft so teach the OTU crews how to defend the aircraft. The main base was [[RAF Pershore]] with Long Marston used as a satellite between 1 July 1943 and 21 August 1944.<ref name="AAFLU"/>
After the war the airfield began to wind down with training flights becoming less frequent and soon after was under the control of No. 3 Maintenance Group from [[RAF Little Rissington]] until 1954.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.longmarstonmodelairshow.co.uk/History.aspx |title=History of RAF Long Marston |publisher=Long Marston Model Airshow |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
